title: Paper: Midwifery FQE January 2020
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Community Health Nursing (Midwifery) - January 2020

questions.question: The statement 'last menstrual period' means:

options.text: The first day of the last menses that the woman had
The last day of the last menses that the woman had
The last month the woman had menses
The monthly period that occurred the month the woman attended the antenatal clinic

questions.explanation: In obstetrics, the Last Menstrual Period (LMP) specifically refers to the first day of bleeding of the last normal menstrual period. This specific date is used to calculate gestational age and the Expected Date of Delivery (EDD).
questions.hint: It's the very start of the cycle.

questions.question: The part of the fetus that lies in the lower pole of the uterus in a breech presentation is the:
questions.explanation: In breech presentation, the buttocks (podalic pole) lie in the lower uterine segment. The Sacrum is the denominator used to describe the position of the breech.
questions.hint: The bone at the base of the spine.

questions.question: The prelacunar stage of pregnancy happens on:
questions.explanation: The pre-lacunar stage of trophoblast development occurs shortly after implantation begins (around day 7-8), before the appearance of lacunae (fluid-filled spaces) in the syncytiotrophoblast which marks the lacunar stage (approx. Day 9).

questions.question: Pregnant women experience tingling/pricking sensation around the nipple between 3rd to 4th week of pregnancy as a result of:

options.text: Increased levels of estrogen in the blood
Decreased levels of estrogen in the blood
Increased levels of human gonadotrophic hormone
Increased blood supply around the nipple area

questions.explanation: Early breast changes, such as tingling, sensitivity, and heaviness, are primarily due to increased vascularity (blood supply) and hormonal changes preparing the breast for lactation.

questions.question: Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test is done to detect the presence of:
questions.explanation: VDRL is a non-treponemal screening test for Syphilis (caused by Treponema pallidum).
questions.hint: A sexually transmitted infection caused by a spirochete.

questions.question: Cervical effacement refers to:

options.text: Inclusion of the cervix from the lower uterine segment
Exclusion of the cervix from the lower uterine segment
Inclusion of the upper segment of the uterus

questions.explanation: Effacement is the shortening and thinning of the cervix where the cervical canal is 'taken up' or included into the lower uterine segment, essentially merging with it.
questions.hint: The cervix shortens and merges upwards.

questions.question: In the normal labour process, the membranes usually rupture:

options.text: Just before the onset of the 1st stage of labour
When the midwife performs the first vaginal examination
At the end of the 1st stage of labour

questions.explanation: Physiologically, membranes typically rupture at the end of the first stage of labor (full dilation) when the support of the cervix is gone and the pressure of the fetal head increases.
questions.hint: When the door is fully open.

questions.question: During labour, frequency, length and strength of contractions are monitored and recorded every:
questions.explanation: Standard monitoring protocols (like the WHO Partograph) recommend assessing and recording uterine contractions every 30 minutes during the active phase of labor.

questions.question: The normal fetal heart rate during labour should range:
questions.explanation: The normal baseline fetal heart rate is between 110 and 160 beats per minute. Rates outside this range may indicate distress.
questions.hint: Faster than an adult's heart rate.

questions.question: During an internal rotation, the presenting part rotates:

options.text: 1/8 of a circle when it meets the pelvic floor
1/4 of a circle when it meets the pelvic floor
1/5 of a circle when it meets the pelvic floor
1/6 of a circle when it meets the pelvic floor

questions.explanation: In a normal anterior position (LOA or ROA), the head rotates 1/8th of a circle (45 degrees) anteriorly to bring the occiput behind the symphysis pubis.

questions.question: Early clamping of the cord as part of active management of the 3rd stage of labour should be done in the first:
questions.explanation: While historic AMTSL protocols suggested immediate clamping, current guidelines recommend delayed clamping (1-3 minutes) to improve neonatal iron stores. Option C best reflects this clinical window.

questions.question: A diagnosis of retained placenta is made when:

options.text: Placenta remains undelivered 30 minutes after the baby's birth
Part of the placenta goes missing
Placenta remains undelivered 1 hour after the baby's birth
Placenta remains undelivered 5 minutes after baby's birth

questions.explanation: Retained placenta is defined as the failure of the placenta to be expelled within 30 minutes after the delivery of the baby, despite active management.

questions.question: A midwife will diagnose occipital posterior position when, on abdominal examination:

options.text: The occiput is easily palpable at the fundus
There is a saucer shaped depression at or near the umbilicus
The occiput is easily palpable at the lower pole of the uterus

questions.explanation: In an Occipito-Posterior (OP) position, the fetal back is posterior. The limbs are anterior, creating a dip or 'saucer-shaped depression' around the umbilicus during abdominal palpation.
questions.hint: A hollow near the belly button.

questions.question: A complete breech is where by:

options.text: The breech presents with hips flexed and legs extended on the abdomen
One or both feet present at the lower pole of the uterus
One or both hips are extended with knees flexed
Hips and knees are both flexed with feet tucked in beside the buttocks

questions.explanation: Complete Breech: Both hips and knees are flexed (sitting cross-legged). Frank Breech: Hips flexed, knees extended. Footling: Hips extended.

questions.question: The recommended calorie intake requirement for a woman in labour is approximately:
questions.explanation: Labor is energy-intensive. Caloric needs to prevent ketosis are approximately 50-100 kcal per hour.

questions.question: The Lovset's maneuver is used:

options.text: In the birth of extended legs
In the birth of extended arms
When there is delay of the birth of the head

questions.explanation: Lovset's maneuver involves rotating the fetal body to deliver extended arms/shoulders during a breech birth.
questions.hint: Used for stuck arms in breech.

questions.question: A woman ruptures membranes and the midwife observes the cord lying outside the vaginal canal. The immediate action he/she will take is:

options.text: Cover the cord with a clean cloth
Pack the vaginal canal with cotton wool
Replace the cord gently back into the vaginal canal
Instruct the woman to lie still in bed

questions.explanation: This is Cord Prolapse. The priority is to relieve pressure on the cord to prevent asphyxia. Instructing the woman to lie down (and elevating hips/Trendelenburg) relieves pressure. Replacing the cord causes spasm. Packing is contraindicated.
questions.hint: Stop gravity from pushing the baby onto the cord.

questions.question: Hypovolemic shock in a woman who is newly delivered is mostly caused by:
questions.explanation: Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) is the most common cause of hypovolemic shock in the immediate postpartum period.

questions.question: Assessment of blood pressure in a woman who has had a normal delivery in the last one hour is done:

options.text: To provide a baseline recording for monitoring her condition
To check whether she is hypertensive
To decide how to control a rise in the same
To enable diagnosis of a heart condition

questions.explanation: Monitoring BP in the 4th stage provides a baseline to detect deviations like hypotension (shock/hemorrhage) or hypertension (preeclampsia).

questions.question: The placenta is fully functional by:
questions.explanation: By the 12th week (end of the first trimester), the placenta is fully formed and takes over the production of progesterone from the corpus luteum.

questions.question: A midwife delivered a baby and after cutting the cord, rapidly dried the baby with a green towel. She/he was reducing the risk for:
questions.explanation: Evaporation of amniotic fluid from the wet skin is a major source of heat loss. Rapid drying prevents hypothermia.
questions.hint: Preventing the baby from getting cold.

questions.question: A woman came to the antenatal clinic for the 1st visit, her LMP was 13/11/2019. Her EDD will be on:
questions.explanation: Using Naegele's Rule: Day + 7 (13+7=20), Month - 3 (Nov[11]-3 = Aug[8]), Year + 1 (2019+1 = 2020). Result: 20/08/2020.

questions.question: The fetal membranes that make up the amniotic sac are the:
questions.explanation: The amniotic sac consists of two layers: the inner Amnion (smooth) and the outer Chorion (rough).

questions.question: The leading direct cause of maternal mortality is:
questions.explanation: Obstetric hemorrhage (specifically PPH) is the leading direct cause of maternal death globally.

questions.question: The fetal heart rate is determined by:
questions.explanation: Fetal heart rate is assessed by listening (Auscultation) using a Pinard stethoscope or Doppler.

questions.question: In a fetal skull the normal diameter that engages in the motherâ€™s pelvis in vertex presentation is the:
questions.explanation: In a well-flexed vertex presentation, the smallest diameter, Sub-occipito-bregmatic (9.5 cm), engages.
questions.hint: The smallest diameter for the best fit.

questions.question: Indicators of an active phase of labour include:

options.text: Frequent contractions occurring every 3-5 minutes, progressive dilatation of the cervix
Progressive dilatation of the cervix, contraction occurring every 5-10 minutes
A soft and pliable cervix, frequent contractions occurring every 3-5 minutes
Frequent contractions occurring every 10 minutes, progressive cervical dilatation

questions.explanation: The active phase is characterized by regular, strong contractions (3-4 in 10 mins) and rapid cervical dilation.

questions.question: One of the following is the most important document in the management of labour:
questions.explanation: The Partograph is the key tool for monitoring labor progress and detecting complications like obstructed labor early.
questions.hint: The chart used to plot labor progress.

questions.question: Meconium stained amniotic fluid during labour when the presentation is cephalic is an indication of:
questions.explanation: In cephalic presentation, meconium indicates fetal hypoxia (distress) causing anal sphincter relaxation. In breech, it can be normal due to compression.

questions.question: Artificial rupture of membranes is indicated when:

options.text: Reduction of amniotic fluid in polyhydramnios is desired

questions.explanation: ARM (Amniotomy) is a standard method to augment labor progress. While it helps in polyhydramnios, 'Augmentation' is the most common indication for progress.

questions.question: A fundus that is at the xiphisternum describes a pregnancy that is at gestation:
questions.explanation: The fundal height reaches its peak at the xiphisternum at 36 weeks before lightening occurs.

questions.question: A cephalohaematoma forms when:

options.text: Bleeding occurs at the base of the fetal skull
There is bleeding between the periosteum and the bones of the fetal skull
A vessel ruptures in the brain of a fetus labour
Fetal skull bones fracture during labour

questions.explanation: Cephalohaematoma is a collection of blood between the skull bone and the periosteum. It does not cross suture lines.
questions.hint: Bleeding under the 'skin' of the bone.

questions.question: An antenatal mother is supposed to attend the antenatal clinic for at least:
questions.explanation: Traditionally, Focused Antenatal Care (FANC) recommended a minimum of 4 comprehensive visits. (Note: New WHO guidelines suggest 8 contacts, but 4 is the standard FANC answer).

questions.question: The drug of choice for routine anticonvulsant management of a woman with eclampsia is:
questions.explanation: Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4) is the gold standard for preventing and controlling eclamptic seizures.

questions.question: The type of anemia common among pregnant women is:
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency is the most common cause of anemia in pregnancy due to high fetal demands and hemodilution.

questions.question: Maternal specific risks factors for pre-eclampsia include:

options.text: Chromosomal abnormalities, extremes of age, nulliparity
Diabetes, extremes of age, renal disease
Urinary tract infections, chromosomal abnormalities, renal disease
Renal disease, urinary tract infection, hydatidiform mole

questions.explanation: Maternal risk factors include pre-existing medical conditions like Diabetes, Renal disease, Hypertension, and extremes of maternal age.

questions.question: An individual birth plan includes:

options.text: Expected date of delivery, identification of a birth companion, health message on personal hygiene
Identification of a possible blood donor, transport to be used before and after delivery, advise on good nutrition
Identification of a birth companion, a possible blood donor, instructions on care of the nipple
Expected date of delivery, identification of a possible blood donor, information on danger signs of the new born

questions.explanation: A birth plan focuses on logistics and emergency preparedness: Place of birth, Attendant, Funds, Transport, Blood Donor, and recognizing Danger Signs.

questions.question: One of the indications of vacuum extraction is:
questions.explanation: Vacuum is used to assist delivery when the second stage is prolonged due to poor expulsive efforts or maternal exhaustion.

questions.question: Causes of fetal distress during labour include:

options.text: Obstructed labour, cord prolapse, ante-partum haemorrhage
Antepartum haemorrhage, fetal congenital malformation, malaria in pregnancy
Antepartum haemorrhage, fetal congenital malformations, obstructed labour
Utero-placental insufficiency, cord presentation, prolonged labour

questions.explanation: Acute intrapartum events like obstruction (compression), cord prolapse (no oxygen), and APH (blood loss) rapidly cause fetal distress.

questions.question: A baby whose APGAR score is less than 7 after 5 minutes post delivery is managed for at least 24 hours in the:
questions.explanation: Low APGAR scores (<7) at 5 minutes necessitate observation and care in a specialized Newborn Unit (NBU).

questions.question: State FIVE precautions taken by a midwife to prevent fetal distress during labour. (Select 5)

options.text: Regular monitoring of Fetal Heart Rate
Use Partograph to detect obstruction early

questions.explanation: Precautions: Position (prevent hypotension), Monitor FHR, Hydrate, Partograph (prevent prolonged labor), and judicious Oxytocin use.

questions.question: Explain the key components of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL). (Select 3)
questions.explanation: AMTSL steps: 1. Uterotonic, 2. CCT, 3. Uterine Massage.

questions.question: State FOUR causes of coagulopathy (clotting failure) in obstetrics. (Select 4)
questions.explanation: Conditions causing DIC: Abruption, Severe Pre-eclampsia, AFE, IUFD.

questions.question: Outline FIVE aims of focused antenatal care. (Select 5)

options.text: Early Detection and Treatment of Complications

questions.explanation: Aims: Education, Prevention, Detection, Planning (Birth/Emergency), and PMTCT.

questions.question: Explain THREE benefits of early initiation of breast feeding. (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Early feeding helps the uterus contract, protects the baby, and bonds the pair.
questions.hint: Good for mom's bleeding and baby's immunity.

questions.question: State FOUR health messages you would give to a post-natal mother on nutrition. (Select 4)

options.text: Eat a balanced diet with all food groups

questions.explanation: Nutrition advice: Balanced diet, Fluids, Iron-rich foods, Supplements.
questions.hint: Eat well to heal and feed.

questions.question: Outline FIVE risk factors for preterm labour. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: Risks: Infections, Overdistension (twins), Medical conditions, Uterine issues, PROM.
questions.hint: Things that stress the uterus or baby.

questions.question: State FIVE signs of obstruction of labour on vaginal examination. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: Signs of obstruction: Caput, Moulding, Edema, Dryness, High head.
questions.hint: Signs of pressure and stuck baby.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for managing primary Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) in order:
questions.explanation: PPH Protocol: Shout for help -> Rub the uterus -> Drugs/Fluids -> Find the cause.
questions.hint: Help first, then stop the bleeding.
